docs.abstract: An Energy Department photographer says he was fired for exposing the coal industry’s influence with the Energy secretary.
docs.snippet: An Energy Department photographer says he was fired for exposing the coal industry’s influence with the Energy secretary.
docs.lead_paragraph: As a photographer for the Department of Energy, Simon Edelman regularly attended meetings with Secretary Rick Perry and snapped pictures for official purposes.

headline.main: He Leaked a Photo of Rick Perry Hugging a Coal Executive. Then He Lost His Job.
headline.print_headline: Photographer Who Shot Bear Hug of Coal Baron Seeks Protections

docs.abstract: The combination of wild stock markets and regulators loosening capital requirements translated into bumper profits for Citigroup and JPMorgan.
docs.snippet: The combination of wild stock markets and regulators loosening capital requirements translated into bumper profits for Citigroup and JPMorgan.
docs.lead_paragraph: Turbulent markets and relaxed regulations are great news for banks — and it shows.

headline.main: Bank Earnings Boom as Regulators Relax Rules
headline.print_headline: Big Banks Report an Earnings Boom Amid Lax Rules and Turbulent Markets

docs.abstract: Part of a wave that includes “Roseanne” and “Will & Grace,” Candice Bergen will return to TV, along with the show’s creator, Diane English.
docs.snippet: Part of a wave that includes “Roseanne” and “Will & Grace,” Candice Bergen will return to TV, along with the show’s creator, Diane English.
docs.lead_paragraph: If it was a hit in the 1980s or 1990s, there’s a good chance it will be back soon.

headline.main: Welcome Back, Murphy Brown: CBS Joins the Reboot Craze

docs.abstract: Hanna Ingber, editorial director of The Times Reader Center, provided a how-to on using social media to converse with readers on topics from race to the weather.
docs.snippet: Hanna Ingber, editorial director of The Times Reader Center, provided a how-to on using social media to converse with readers on topics from race to the weather.
docs.lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Hanna Ingber, editorial director of The Times’s Reader Center, discussed the tech she’s using.

headline.main: Twitter, Facebook, Slack: Using Every Tool to Hear What Readers Think
headline.print_headline: Hearing From Readers Over Multiple Channels

docs.abstract: The delivery giant is claiming compensation after a European court annulled a decision by regulators to block a 2013 deal for its Dutch rival.
docs.snippet: The delivery giant is claiming compensation after a European court annulled a decision by regulators to block a 2013 deal for its Dutch rival.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — United Parcel Service has sued European antitrust regulators for a decision they made five years ago that blocked its takeover of the Dutch delivery company TNT Express, according to a record of court proceedings published on Monday.

headline.main: U.P.S. Seeks More Than $2 Billion in Damages Over TNT Bid

docs.abstract: Macy’s is the latest company trying to capture a piece of the lucrative Muslim clothing market, which was worth $254 billion globally in 2016.
docs.snippet: Macy’s is the latest company trying to capture a piece of the lucrative Muslim clothing market, which was worth $254 billion globally in 2016.
docs.lead_paragraph: Macy’s will introduce a collection of modest clothing, including hijabs, next week, making it the latest company to try to capture a piece of the lucrative Muslim clothing market.

headline.main: Macy’s Courts Muslims With New Hijab Brand
headline.print_headline: Macy’s Courts Muslims  With a New Hijab Brand

byline.original: By Christina Caron and Maya Salam

docs.abstract: The prizes encompassed, among other topics, stories of abuse in the workplace; construction of a U.S.-Mexico border wall; and a profile of Dylann Roof, who was charged with killing several people in a Charleston, S.C., church.
docs.snippet: The prizes encompassed, among other topics, stories of abuse in the workplace; construction of a U.S.-Mexico border wall; and a profile of Dylann Roof, who was charged with killing several people in a Charleston, S.C., church.
docs.lead_paragraph: Investigations by The New York Times and Ronan Farrow, 30, of The New Yorker that revealed allegations of sexual harassment and the subsequent silencing of the victims helped topple powerful men — including in Hollywood, politics and Silicon Valley — and prompted a wave of women to share their experiences with abuse. Reporting on accusations against Bill O’Reilly, the former Fox News host, and Harvey Weinstein, the film mogul, inspired the global #MeToo movement that has opened new conversations about gender and power dynamics in the workplace.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: Gulf: The Making of an American Sea (Book)

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: Prairie Fires: The American Dreams of Laura Ingalls Wilder (Book)

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: Locking Up Our Own: Crime and Punishment in Black America (Book)

docs.abstract: The president’s $200 billion plan recasts the federal government as a minority stakeholder in the nation’s new infrastructure projects.
docs.snippet: The president’s $200 billion plan recasts the federal government as a minority stakeholder in the nation’s new infrastructure projects.
docs.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s $200 billion plan to rebuild America upends the criteria that have long been used to pick ambitious federal projects, putting little emphasis on how much an infrastructure proposal benefits the public and more on finding private investors and other outside sources of money.

headline.main: Trump’s Infrastructure Plan Puts Burden on State and Private Money
headline.print_headline: Infrastructure To Rely on Cash From Investors

byline.original: By Patricia Cohen and Alan Rappeport

docs.abstract: A ring of cybercriminals tapped into cash registers at retail stores to obtain the card numbers, then offered them for sale, a security firm said.
docs.snippet: A ring of cybercriminals tapped into cash registers at retail stores to obtain the card numbers, then offered them for sale, a security firm said.
docs.lead_paragraph: Saks has been hacked — adding to the already formidable challenges faced by the luxury retailer.

headline.main: Card Data Stolen From 5 Million Saks and Lord & Taylor Customers
headline.print_headline: Hackers Stole Data From Millions of Cards at Saks

byline.original: By Vindu Goel and Rachel Abrams

docs.abstract: A new company report blames a culture that focused on profitability for a falsified data scandal that has cast a shadow over Japan’s reputation for quality.
docs.snippet: A new company report blames a culture that focused on profitability for a falsified data scandal that has cast a shadow over Japan’s reputation for quality.
docs.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Kobe Steel said on Tuesday that its top executive would resign, after a falsified data scandal that shook Japan Inc. and led other manufacturers to come clean about their broken pledges to meet top quality standards.

headline.main: Kobe Steel’s Chief to Step Down as It Discloses Wider Quality Problems
headline.print_headline: Kobe Steel’s Chief to Resign As Quality Scandal Widens

byline.original: By Makiko Inoue and Hisako Ueno
